citations.narrative:
Eight adult cats are housed in two rooms where the ambient temperature is not adequately maintained. Four of the cats,
housed together in a room in a building called the "Big Trailer", had ice floating in both their water bowls. The air
temperature (measured with a Kestrel 3000) at floor level near the water bowls was 37.7 degrees Fahrenheit. The air
temperature about 6 feet above the floor, was 52 degrees. The licensee said there is no insulation under the floor which
has a crawl space underneath that is open to the outdoor air. There is also a gap under the door, near the water bowls,
where non-conditioned air can enter. The cats were on resting surfaces near the ceiling and did not appear stressed or
uncomfortable. The 4 other cats are housed together in room in a building called the "Breeding Trailer". The temperature
in the room was 48.2 degrees. Both rooms are heated by space heaters that the licensee said cannot be turned up any
higher. At the time of the inspection, 9:30 am, the outdoor temperature was 13 degrees. The overnight low temperature
had been about 5 degrees in the area. Ambient temperatures in enclosures must not fall below 45 degrees for more than
4 hours when cats are present. The temperature near the water and food bowls in the "Big Trailer" were still below this
level. The ambient temperature in the "Breeding Trailer" at the time of inspection would suggest the temperature had
likely fallen below this level during the night. Outdoor temperatures for 5 of the next 7 days are forecast to only be in the
single digits with overnight lows below zero. Indoor housing facilities for cats must be sufficiently heated when necessary
to protect the cats from temperature extremes and to provide for their health and well-being.
To be corrected by: February 14, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.2(a) 
   
Indoor housing facilities. 
Eight adult cats are housed in two rooms where the ambient temperature is not adequately maintained. Four of the cats, 
housed together in a room in a building called the "Big Trailer", had ice floating in both their water bowls. The air 
temperature (measured with a Kestrel 3000) at floor level near the water bowls was 37.7 degrees Fahrenheit. The air 
temperature about 6 feet above the floor, was 52 degrees. The licensee said there is no insulation under the floor which 
has a crawl space underneath that is open to the outdoor air. There is also a gap under the door, near the water bowls, 
where non-conditioned air can enter. The cats were on resting surfaces near the ceiling and did not appear stressed or 
uncomfortable. The 4 other cats are housed together in room in a building called the "Breeding Trailer". The temperature 
in the room was 48.2 degrees. Both rooms are heated by space heaters that the licensee said cannot be turned up any 
higher. At the time of the inspection, 9:30 am, the outdoor temperature was 13 degrees. The overnight low temperature 
had been about 5 degrees in the area. Ambient temperatures in enclosures must not fall below 45 degrees for more than 
4 hours when cats are present. The temperature near the water and food bowls in the "Big Trailer" were still below this 
level. The ambient temperature in the "Breeding Trailer" at the time of inspection would suggest the temperature had 
likely fallen below this level during the night. Outdoor temperatures for 5 of the next 7 days are forecast to only be in the 
single digits with overnight lows below zero. Indoor housing facilities for cats must be sufficiently heated when necessary 
to protect the cats from temperature extremes and to provide for their health and well-being. 
To be corrected by: February 14, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
